item.title: Sinosphere Blog: One Week After the Tianjin Blasts: What We Know
item.description: The scale of the disaster — in terms of lives lost, environmental pollution, property destruction and economic costs — is beginning to emerge.
item.category: Rui Hai International Logistics Co Ltd
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: An aerial view of what remained of warehouses in Tianjin after the fire and explosions.

item.title: Chinese Report Details Role of Political Connections in Tianjin Blasts
item.description: The state-run news agency described how two major shareholders in a company gained government approvals for the warehouse where the explosions took place.
item.category: Rui Hai International Logistics Co Ltd
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Israeli Court to Rule on Release of Palestinian Staging Hunger Strike
item.description: Lawyers for Mohammad Allan could not obtain his consent on a tentative offer that would have granted him freedom by November because his mental state had deteriorated, an official said.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: A poster of Mohammad Allan, a Palestinian prisoner on a hunger strike, displayed during a protest in Rahat, Israel, on Tuesday calling for his release.

item.title: ISIS Said to Behead Syrian Antiquities Scholar in Palmyra
item.description: The body of Khaled al-Asaad was then hung from one of the town’s Roman columns, Syrian state news media and an activist group said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:credit: Directorate-General of Antiquities and Museums, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Khaled al-Asaad, the retired chief archaeologist of the ancient Syrian city of Palmyra.

item.title: German Parliament Approves Greek Bailout Deal
item.description: Sixty-three conservatives voted against the agreement and three abstained, suggesting that Chancellor Angela Merkel would find it hard to get more help for Greece in the future.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel in Parliament on Wednesday. Her finance minister, Wolfgang Schäuble, laid out the government’s case for a bailout deal for Greece.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Blind Faith in China’s Stock Market
item.description: The allure of quick profits tempted many Chinese people to gamble their savings in stocks.
item.dc:creator: YU HUA

item.title: Activist Targeting Modi’s Government Becomes Government’s Target
item.description: Teesta Setalvad, who seeks to hold the Indian prime minister responsible for deadly riots in 2002, has been overwhelmed by attacks emanating from entities controlled by him or his allies.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARSTOW
item.media:credit: Manpreet Romana for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Indian rights activist Teesta Setalvad, center, with Rupa Mody, left, and Saira Sandhi, who both lost family members during riots in 2002 that killed more than 1,000 people in Gujarat. Ms. Setalvad is campaigning to hold Prime Minister Narendra Modi criminally responsible for the riots.

item.title: Gabon’s President Offers Some of His Wealth ‘to the People’
item.description: The move by Ali Ben Bongo, one of Africa’s wealthiest leaders, was heralded by his circle but met with skepticism from critics who pointed out the legal and political pressure he faces.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: President Ali Ben Bongo of Gabon.

item.title: Tony Gleaton, 67, Dies, Leaving Legacy in Pictures of Africans in the Americas
item.description: Mr. Gleaton traveled light, by bus, without assistants, complex equipment or luxury lodgings, to document the lives of black cowboys and create images of the African diaspora in Latin America.
item.dc:creator: BRUCE WEBER
item.media:description: Tony Gleaton in a 1998 photograph. His career began in the fashion industry but quickly took a sharp turn.

item.title: One Palestinian’s Refusal to Eat Puts Israel in a Bind
item.description: The case has received extraordinary attention because it unfolded as Israel passed a law concerning the force-feeding of hunger strikers.
item.category: Adalah, The Legal Center for Arab Minority Rights in Israel
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN and DIAA HADID
item.media:description: Supporters held a photo of Mohammad Allan, the Palestinian hunger striker, during a rally on Tuesday in southern Israel.

item.title: Robert Menendez Says He’ll Vote Against Iran Nuclear Deal
item.description: Senator Robert Menendez, a Democrat, said the agreement did not go far enough to limit Tehran’s potential to pursue a weapons program.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: World Briefing: South Sudan: U.S. Threatens Sanctions Over Rejection of Pact
item.description: The White House chastised President Salva Kiir of South Sudan on Tuesday for refusing to sign a peace agreement to halt that nation’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: World Briefing: W.H.O. Calls ‘Vaccine Hesitancy’ an Increasing Concern Globally
item.description: The organization called the problem “a growing challenge for countries seeking to close the immunization gap.”
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Libya Asks Arab League Countries to Help Battle Islamic State
item.description: An appeal that risks new regional entanglements in what is already at least a three-way conflict among the Islamic State and two rival Libyan factions.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Pro-government fighters in Benghazi in March. The Islamic State and two rival Libyan factions are each seeking sway over Libya and its vast oil reserves.

item.title: Elections Seem Likely in Turkey as ISIS Threat Rises
item.description: Talks aimed at forming a coalition government ended, and an Islamic State video called on Muslims to revolt against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: German Vote on Bailout Carries Risks for Merkel
item.description: Despite a rebellion in Parliament, the German chancellor is expected to win approval of the 86-billion-euro bailout package for Greece in a Wednesday vote.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Rogelio Livieres Plano, Bishop Ousted by Pope Francis, Dies at 69
item.description: Bishop Livieres, a conservative clergyman in Paraguay, sheltered a priest accused of molestation and made him vicar general, responsible for handling accusations of sexual abuse.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: Gabon’s President Offers Some of His Wealth ‘to the People’
item.description: The move by Ali Ben Bongo, one of Africa’s wealthiest leaders, was heralded by his circle but met with skepticism from critics who pointed out the legal and political pressure he faces.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: President Ali Ben Bongo of Gabon.

item.title: Fear of Toxic Air and Distrust of Government Follow Tianjin Blasts
item.description: The government has insisted that it ensured the safety of the city’s air, but after rain on Tuesday, the streets began to foam.
item.category: Rui Hai International Logistics Co Ltd
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: Police officers and soldiers attended a memorial service for victims of the Tianjin blasts near the disaster's epicenter on Tuesday.

item.title: Russian Police Get Tough on Illicit Cheese
item.description: A series of raids led the authorities to a ring of people suspected of peddling contraband dairy products made with banned Western ingredients.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Making cheese in Krutovo, Russia. The Russian government banned dairy products from a host of Western nations last year.
